text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
IRM 2.21.1 - Updated with current processes, procedures, references and links.
(3) - Changed IRM 1.2.41 reference to IRM 1.2.62, which is the correct reference.
IRM 2.21.1.9 - Updated the Request Funding Section to capture the new, streamlined Unfunded Requests (UFRs) process developed by Financial Management Services (FMS).
2.21.1.10 - Changed the 508 Compliance Section with the latest guidelines to be referenced.

IRM 2.21.1.11 - Noted in the Determine the Shopping Cart Routing Path Section any exceptions to the IT approval requirement will be documented in a Memorandum of Agreement/Memorandum of Understanding (MOA/MOU) between IT and the Business Unit in accordance with IRM 1.2.1.3.5, Policy Statement 2-93.

IRM 2.21.1.11.1 - Updated the Strategic Supplier Management (SSM) Approval Section to cover when the exercise options and the incremental funding items do not require Strategic Supplier Management (SSM) approval.
IRM 2.21.1.13.2 - Added a new section on Approval of Limited Competition.
IRM 2.21.1, dated November 27, 2019, is superseded.
AUDIENCE
Table of Contents
to Shopping Cart Processing for IT

) Purpose: The purpose of this IRM is to identify the policies, processes and information required to create a Procurement for Public Sector (PPS) and cart for IT products and services and the approvals required during the pro- cessing of the shopping cart. (
) Audience: IRS personnel involved in the creation, review and approval of shopping carts for IT products and services. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Strategic Supplier Management. (
) Program Owner: Program Management (an organization within IT, Strategy Planning). (
) Primary Stakeholders: Procurement; Privacy, Government Liaison and sure (PGLD). (

) Program Goals: Ensure that shopping carts for IT Products/Services have following attributes: a. Required ﬁelds are completed accurately. b. Required acquisition documentation is attached. c. Required reviews are documented. d. Required approvals are obtained. e. Acquisition planning dates are met. (
) IRS IT is responsible for approving the expenditure of IT funding based in cordance with Delegation Order IT-
, Approval of Information ogy (IT) Requisitions. (
) Internal IT organizations and stakeholders have reviews and approvals that need to be documented. (
) Treasury Policy Memorandum for Bureau Chief Information Officers Review and Approval of Information Technology Acquisitions, dated March
, formally establishes the process of Treasury CIO’s review and approval of acquisitions in order to monitor and maintain the effectiveness and IT Acquisition strategies implementation. (
) IRS IT Policy Memorandum for Management of IRS Information Technology, dated July
, communicated the CIO’s responsibilities for managing acquisitions for the IRS as required by the Taxpayer First Act (TFA). (
) IRM

), Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Delegation Authorities for IT Activities, Division/Function Delegation of Authorities for mation Technology (IT), contains the Division/Function delegation orders is- sued by the Chief Information Officer (CIO). In addition, any revised orders are posted on the Publication Management & Resource Services site Delegation Orders. (
) The Department of Treasury’s Federal Information Technology Acquisition Reform Act (FITARA) of

guidance, which delegates to the IRS CIO re- sponsibility for reviewing the acquisition and contract selections and grants Chief Information Officer (CIO) the authority to govern all areas related to mation Resources and Technology Management. Internal Revenue Manual

In addition, any revised delegation orders are posted on the Publication Management & Resource Services web- site Delegation Orders.

) Technical Point of Contact (TPOC): The person who is responsible for with the applicable IRS organization to transform the business requirement a technical requirement and completing the acquisition package. (
) Requestor: The person who enters a shopping cart into PPS and tracks it through the approval path to Procurement. (

) Signatory Authority Approver: The person who has the responsibility to the shopping cart is fully compliant with IRS requirements and has the authority to approve shopping carts up to a speciﬁed dollar amount as described in Delegation Order IT-
) Financial Plan Manager (FPM): The person who manages the overall within the ﬁnancial plans under their control and approves shopping carts in accordance with IRM
, Financial Accounting, Establishing and Obligations. (

) Program Reports a. PPS Report: The PPS Report is reviewed to ensure that shopping Management created outside of Information Technology have gone through the priate Information Technology reviews. This report shows shopping generated from PPS that are en-route to Procurement. b. Acquisition Timeliness: The date that shopping carts reached Procure- ment is compared to Procurement’s Acquisition Planning Due Dates for the ﬁscal year to determine if they are timely. Strategic Supplier ment (SSM) provides a report to measure each ACIO’s timeliness of shopping carts. (

) Program Effectiveness: a. This IRM is reviewed annually to ensure that the information about required reviews and the shopping cart creation process are current. Feedback on the effectiveness of the required reviews is shared with responsible stakeholder organizations for consideration as part of the

) Sensitive But Unclassiﬁed (SBU) Information: All IRS acquisitions and vehicles contain appropriate language holding contractors and other service providers accountable for complying with federal and IRS privacy policies procedures. SBU refers to any information that if lost, stolen, misused, accessed or altered without proper authorization, may adversely affect the national interest or the conduct of federal programs (including IRS or the privacy to which individuals are entitled under the Privacy Act. 2.21 Shopping Cart Processing for Technology Products and Services
When an ACIO requires funding that was not planned in the current year budget the amount needed exceeds what is available, the ACIO can submit an Unfunded Request (UFR) to the CIO. (
) For unfunded shopping carts, obtain the accounting codes from Project Manager and include them on the Funding Template. (

) Procurement may return an approved unfunded shopping cart to the FPM to add funding. a. If changes have been made to the acquisition package that require tional levels of approval, the shopping cart must go through the same approvals as a new requirement. b. If no changes have been made that require a difference level of the FPM will send the shopping cart directly back to Procurement once the funds are added. (
) An acquisition package must be sent to Procurement, so the Acquisition Planning Due Date is met, especially when the acquisition need is for the quarter of the next ﬁscal year. (

) Enterprise Systems Management Review (ESMRVW) – All hardware, and cloud technologies must be approved and reviewed by Enterprise Archi- tecture (EA); and posted on the Enterprise Standards Proﬁle (ESP). EA man- ages at the major release level, so upgrades to the next or “newer” version not automatically approved. Please send an email to the EA office at *EA Change Requests or ea.change.requests@irs.gov with the subject title ping Cart – Request to buy Technology” and provide EA the vendor name, product name, and major version of the technology being purchased. EA will look up product to verify it’s in the ESP. For any technologies being re- quested that are not in the ESP, requester will be given instructions via a separate correspondence on how to submit an Enterprise Architecture Enter- prise Standards Proﬁle Change Request for ESP inclusion. Attach the email approval from the EA Office to the shopping cart as evidence of compliance. You can ﬁnd additional references and guidance in IRM
, Enterprise chitecture (EA), EA Overview. (

) Technical Tier III Review: This tier consists of end-user computing-related hardware, software, maintenance and related services, including desktops, laptops and personal communication devices. i. All acquisitions for workstation/Tier
software licenses, subscriptions, maintenance, including for off network and Cloud based products, require III approval. Approval requests should be emailed to the *IT T
Software view mailbox or email IT.T

Software.Review@irs.gov. Approval requests include publisher name, product name, license type, quantity, version, Period of Performance and the applicable End User License Agreement (EULA). ii. Once approval has been obtained, the applicable review completion/ approval e-mail(s) must be attached to the shopping cart. (

) Enterprise Hardware Asset Management Review: This review consists of prise IT hardware, hardware maintenance and related services. Every acquisition for new and maintenance hardware must have Hardware Asset Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

page Management (HW AM) review email approval. i. Every acquisition for new trackable hardware and hardware maintenance must have Hardware Asset Management (HW AM) review email approval. Email requests must be sent to *IT Asset Management Review mailbox or email IT.EUES.AM.REQ@irs.gov to be reviewed and to prepare for proper set barcoding, tracking, management and shipment conﬁrmation. Asset (barcoding) of new hardware purchases must be included for a quantity of or more assets. At a minimum, the list must contain barcodes, serial numbers, brand, model, tion, and Period of Performance (POP) dates of the hardware assets. The of hardware assets will be validated with the information from HP Asset ager (KISAM). ii. Once approval has been obtained, the applicable review completion/ approval e-mail(s) must be attached to the shopping cart in the “Notes and Attachments”. (

2.21 Shopping Cart Processing for Information Technology Products and Services
FMS Financial Plan Manager approves IT shopping carts in accordance with IRM 1.35.24, Financial Accounting, Establishing Commitments and
IT shopping carts initiated by a non-IT BOD must be routed to the Appropriate ACIO for review and approval only after FMS has approved funding.
Exception: Any exceptions to the IT approval requirement will be documented in an MOU between IT and the Business Unit in accordance with IRM 1.2.1.3.5, Policy Statement 2-93.
, Policy Statement

A shopping cart is required to exercise an option. The SSM Director or designee approval is required on shopping carts for: a. Bailment agreements, no cost demonstrations, Request for (RFI), Market Research Requests or evaluation agreements for hardware, managed services and “cloud” based services, regardless dollar value; b. “Pilot IRS” shopping carts (a program under which a more procurement process allows a company to propose an innovative to an IRS problem and receive technical and actionable feedback in weeks instead of months regardless of dollar value); c. Infrastructure acquisitions (e.g., servers, mainframes, managed services, “cloud” based services) and infrastructure-related services with an Independent Government Cost Estimate (IGCE) than or equal to $

Infrastructure-related services are supporting the delivery, installation and initial conﬁguration of the new infrastructure; d. Software acquisitions with an IGCE greater than or equal to For clarity, shopping carts in the following categories do not require SSM approval: a. Services supporting non-infrastructure-related work, such as cyber analysis, data analysis, business process improvement and other services not directly related to IT infrastructure installation or tion; b. Exercise of option periods for previously approved contracts are not required to be approved again unless the scope has been modiﬁed; c. Incremental funding items do not require approval again when an from a previously approved cart is attached SSM review will be conducted prior to ACIO/Director/Senior Manager of the shopping cart via Procurement for Public Sector (PPS) routing. The following describes the scope of the review: a. Evaluate if similar, in-place agreements or capabilities could be used requirements could be combined to improve economies of scale to reduce costs to the IRS.

The SSM Director or designee approval is required on shopping carts for: a. Bailment agreements, no cost demonstrations, Request for Information (RFI), Market Research Requests or evaluation agreements for software, hardware, managed services and “cloud” based services, regardless of dollar value; b. “Pilot IRS” shopping carts (a program under which a more streamlined procurement process allows a company to propose an innovative solution to an IRS problem and receive technical and actionable feedback in weeks instead of months regardless of dollar value); c. Infrastructure acquisitions (e.g., servers, mainframes, network/telecom, managed services, “cloud” based services) and infrastructure-related services with an Independent Government Cost Estimate (IGCE) greater than or equal to $
Infrastructure-related services are services supporting the delivery, installation and initial conﬁguration of the new infrastructure; d. Software acquisitions with an IGCE greater than or equal to $

b. Conﬁrm required documentation (PWS/SOW, LSJ, IGCE, Market Research, Acquisition Plan) has been submitted. c. Validate the documentation reasonably and accurately describes the re- quirements of the proposed acquisition. (

) In support of this review, Program/Project Managers, Acquisition Program Managers (APMs) and TPOCs/CORs are encouraged to contact SSM as as upcoming requirements are identiﬁed. SSM reviews will be completed: a. Within
working days after approval request for shopping carts with an IGCE value less than $
; or b.
working days after approval request for shopping carts with an value from $
to $
; or c. Case-by-case basis as determined by Director, SSM or designee, for shopping carts with an IGCE value greater than $
Note: For Shopping Cart that use Surge CLINs or are submitted with limited mentation, further discussions may be required to determine and requirements before approval will be granted. (
) Each ACIO may have their own internal management review process, which may require adding reviewers prior to the Signatory Authority Approver. (
) IT shopping carts initiated by a non-IT BOD must be routed to the ACIO for review and approval only after FMS has conﬁrmed there is funding. (
) The signature authorities and associated redelegations supported by Delega- tion Order IT-
apply to shopping carts for purchases of IT products and services. a. Signature authority up to $

for shopping carts/purchase card actions that support non-IT goods or administrative services (court reporters, movers, executive certiﬁcate framing, fax/printer toner, office supplies) and IT operating costs speciﬁcally associated with tele- communications recurring billing (i.e., local/long distance phone may be approved by the senior manager or frontline manager. b. This authority cannot be redelegated and acting managers are not approved as proxies. The contract writing system (PPS) record must include the approval of the signature authority. Signature authority for shopping carts greater than $

(cumulative) revert to standard IT shopping cart signature authority. c. The Delegation and Signature sheet called Shopping Cart Signature Authority List outlines each level of funding authority. This sheet is updated monthly or whenever an executive change occurs. Due to the length and frequency of senior manager and frontline manager it is not feasible to include these names in the Shopping Cart Signature Authority List. 2.21.1.11.2 (02-23-2021) Signature Authority Approval
(2) IT shopping carts initiated by a non-IT BOD must be routed to the appropriate ACIO for review and approval only after FMS has conﬁrmed there is approved
a. Signature authority up to $

for shopping carts/purchase card actions that support non-IT goods or administrative services (court reporters, movers, executive certiﬁcate framing, fax/printer toner, general office supplies) and IT operating costs speciﬁcally associated with tele- communications recurring billing (i.e., local/long distance phone service) may be approved by the senior manager or frontline manager. b. This authority cannot be redelegated and acting managers are not approved as proxies. The contract writing system (PPS) record must include the approval of the signature authority. (cumulative) revert to standard IT shopping cart signature authority. c. The Delegation and Signature sheet called Shopping Cart Signature Authority List outlines each level of funding authority. This sheet is updated monthly or whenever an executive change occurs. Due to the length and frequency of senior manager and frontline manager changes, it is not feasible to include these names in the Shopping Cart Signature Authority List. The current Shopping Cart Signature Authority List is tained on the IT Delegations Orders website. Shopping Cart Proxy, Actors and Executive Officers or SES in Waiting (SIW) - Situations arise when executives cannot electronically approve shopping carts due to no n-system access such as vacations or conferences.

Shopping Cart Processing for Technology Products and Services a. Executive Officers or SES in Waiting (SIW) in Executive Positions: Executive Officers or SES in Waiting (SIW) are employees who are per- forming in Executive positions but have not completed their executive certiﬁcation. These candidates are authorized to sign as approvers com- mensurate with the level of the position they are ﬁlling. b. Proxies for Executives: Executives who cannot electronically approve shopping carts due to non-system access (such as computer downtime) can designate a proxy staff member on an as-needed basis to perform the electronic signature. The staff person is responsible for obtaining and retaining electronic approval of the proxy delegation (via e-mail) for audit purposes. The staff person performing the proxy action must state in the PPS approval comments section: ″Proxy (name) Approved and signed (title and name) on (date). The e-mail approval of shopping cart is on ﬁle.″ c. Executives Appointing Actors with Same Funding Authority: Execu- tives, who will be unavailable for speciﬁc periods, can appoint another executive to ″act″ in their position. Non-executive staff personnel cannot be given acting authority in terms of approving shopping carts. To clarify the process, the designating executive is the unavailable executive and the executive appointed will be called an actor. When the designating executive and the actor have the same funding level authority, the shopping cart routing path should be changed to the actor’s name instead of the designating executive name. This should be completed before the shopping cart reaches the designating executive in PPS or the document routing becomes an issue in the electronic system. The only remedy when this occurs is for the helpdesk to redirect the shopping cart. Contact the helpdesk via phone (

). d. Executives Appointing Actors with Lower Funding Authority: When designating executive’s funding authority is higher than the actor, a formal ″acting″ document must be generated and retained for audit purposes. This documentation will allow the acting executive to approve shopping carts at the designating executive’s higher funding authority. • This formal acting authorization must be in a memo or email. The au- thorization must contain the actor’s authority for a speciﬁc period. This authorization must be retained by the actor for audit purposes. • When the actor approves a shopping cart, an additional statement be inserted in the PPS approval comment section. The comment should state “Acting for (name) from (date) to (date). Acting documentation on the ﬁle with the Acting Executive.” e. Proxies and Actors for Senior Managers and Frontline Managers: There is no authorization for a senior manager or frontline manager to designate a proxy or an actor to approve shopping carts. Senior or frontline manager unavailability requires approval at a higher level. (

) The Requestor creates the shopping cart using the following guidance to ensure all ﬁelds are completed properly: Cart a. IT Shopping Cart Checklist, which is used to guide the Requestor through entering information in the various tabs in PPS (e.g., General Data tab, Account Assignment tab and Item tab) and the required approval path. This must be completed during the shopping cart and added to the shopping cart attachments. b. Work Step Instructions, which are available for detailed guidance on completing the shopping cart ﬁelds. Note: In case of a Lapse in Appropriation due to a government shutdown, the mation contained in Continuity of Operations (in PPS), Lapse Plan Code and Lapse Plan Justiﬁcation Text, needs review for conﬁrming accuracy or making updates for identifying contractors to continue work during a shutdown . Software Development Prerequisites for more information. (
